The way th=
at fitness is scaled indeed has a significant effect at the speciation leve=
l of NEAT.  Because the number of offspring that a species will produce col=
lectively is proportional to its average fitness (which follows from fitnes=
s sharing in NEAT), scaling fitness in different ways will cause offspring =
to be allocated to species in different proportions.  <br>


<br>
I don&#39=
;t think there is a harm in exponential fitness if you want to emphasize th=
e curve in certain ways.  The same motivations that apply in regulars EAs c=
an apply to NEAT.<br>
<br>
However, the place where fitness scales can hamp=
er NEAT is if they are proportionally too narrow.  For example,  if every s=
pecies has an average fitness between 1001 and 1005, then they will look pr=
actically the same to fitness sharing and will all get roughly the same num=
ber of offspring.  In that case, speciation won't really distinguish mu=
ch between better and worse species.  However, if the average fitnesses wer=
e instead between 1 and 5, then the allocations would vary a lot, with many=
 more offspring going to the 5 species than the 1 (because 5 is 5 times 1).=
  This example shows that the range of fitnesses is not the only important =
consideration.  It is also important how big the range is compared to the a=
bsolute magnitude.<br>


<br>
ken</p><div class=3D"im"><br>
